text: - --30 minutes from now.

Mr. Trump is about to meet
with several influential CEOs
for their take on the economy.

But some of those high-profile
seats are going to be empty.

The Disney CEO, Bob Iger,
won't be going because
of scheduling conflicts.

And earlier, Uber CEO Travis
Kalanick announced that he
is pulling out of the group.

Uber got caught in the huge
backlash around Mr. Trump's

travel ban, and
Kalanick was pressured
about his spot on the council.

Now, let's get an in-depth
look at this council.

Nicholas Thompson is the
editor of "Wired Magazine."

He joins us from San
Francisco via Skype.
Nick, so good to see you.

First, who is still in Trump's
business advisory council,

and what does this
group actually do?

NICHOLAS THOMPSON:
Well, the group

is set up to advise Trump
on the American economy,

and also particularly where
the economy is growing.

And it's actually still
full of luminaries.
You still have Jamie Diamond.
You still have Jack Welch.

You still have the CEOs
of Walmart, PepsiCo,

all kinds of companies, lots
of financial service people.

Where you've really
had the problem
is with the tech industry.

- Now Uber-- we know that Uber
has pulled out of the advisory
body completely.

Is this all because of
the political pressure,
that Delete Uber campaign?

NICHOLAS THOMPSON: There's a
lot of political pressure coming

at Uber, and there's a lot of
political pressure in Silicon

Valley where most
of the companies

are opposed to Donald Trump
in sort of a core sense.

Many of them are
run by immigrants.

A lot of them have a lot of
immigrants working for it.

And most importantly, they
have a lot of young people

who live in Silicon Valley,
who live in California, who

are quite culturally
opposed, politically
opposed to Donald Trump.

And so what's happened
at all of these companies

is that there's been a
little bit of an uprising
of the junior employees.

So Travis Kalanick, who runs
Uber, got in lots of trouble
in a couple of ways.

One, he was perceived that
they were profiteering off

the protests over the ban,
during the airport protests

where they sort of set special
prices for people trying
to get out of the airport.

And then secondly, a lot
of the engineers at Uber
said, what are you doing?

Why are you advising
Donald Trump?

So he said they had 200,000
people deleting their app
as part of the protest.

And these essential employees,
who are so hard to recruit,

so hard to retain, up
in arms, asking him

how he could stay in
this advisory council.
And so he decided to drop out.

- And Nick, despite the, as
you put it, uprising in tech,

Elon Musk says he will
still attend this meeting.

And he also issued a
statement-- we're going to bring
it up for viewers now--

saying this, that "Advisory
councils simply provide advice,

and attending does
not mean that I

agree with actions by the
Administration," unquote.

Musk also says that he plans to
take his travel ban objections
directly to President Trump.
But Nick, will Trump listen?

NICHOLAS THOMPSON:
Well, it's not clear
whether Trump will listen.

You can absolutely understand
Elon Musk's position, which

is, look, Elon Musk has spoken
out against a number of Trump

policies and has been
part of the group that's
been criticizing the ban.

But he also wants a
place at the table.

He wants to be able to
say things to Trump.

He really wants
Trump to understand

the importance of solar
energy, for example,
in space exploration.

And the thing about Elon
Musk is that he is almost
a demigod in Silicon Valley.

And so he can kind
of do what he wants

without having to worry that
his employees are gonna quit.

They're so eager
to work with him.
He's very special.
So he went on Twitter.
He said, hey, everybody.
Give me ideas.
Join the debate.

I think he actually
has handled it well.

I don't think there's gonna
be a backlash against him.
- Yeah.

So either through statements
or through boycotts, a number

of tech companies,
top firms here,

are taking a stance against
Trump, and especially
his immigration ban.

Microsoft-- that company
published this open letter

asking the Trump
administration to consider

exceptions for visa-holding
workers and students.

They also issued this
statement, saying this--

that they are deeply
valued contributors

to the innovation, research, and
business acumen of our nation.

They serve these critical roles
in the successful operations
of American companies.

Nick, these are powerful, very
valuable American tech firms.

But can they sway
President Trump?

NICHOLAS THOMPSON:
Well, it's not clear.

I mean, they're not just
powerful American tech firms.

They are the largest, the second
largest, the fourth largest,

and the sixth largest
companies in the world
by market capitalization.

There is so much money
and so much influence.
These companies are huge.

And they care about this
at a very deep level.

Half of the
billion-dollar companies

that have been
founded in America
have been founded by immigrants.

Half of the companies
in Silicon Valley
are founded by immigrants.

There is a huge immigrant
culture in the tech community

and in this very fast-growing
part of the economy.

That said, it's not clear
how much influence they
will have with Donald Trump.

Clearly he's gonna want
the economy to grow.

Cleary, he's going to
have incentives to have
these companies do well.

But as we've seen, he's a
president with his own opinions

who won't necessarily be
swayed by these writers
and these protests.
- Nick Thompson, always--
